headline: Pork Dumplings
description: These amazingly easy steamed pork dumplings have a tasty filling made with pork, ginger, garlic, and soy sauce for the most delectable Chinese dim sum!
name: Pork Dumplings

recipeInstructions.text: In a large bowl, combine the pork, ginger, garlic, green onion, soy sauce, sesame oil, egg and cabbage. Stir until well mixed.

Place 1 heaping teaspoon of pork filling onto each wonton skin. Moisten edges with water and fold edges over to form a triangle shape. Roll edges slightly to seal in filling. Set dumplings aside on a lightly floured surface until ready to cook.
Arrange dumplings in a covered bamboo or metal steamer so they don't touch to prevent them from sticking together; steam for 15 minutes, or until pork is cooked through.

review.reviewBody: These are delicious but they are time consuming to assemble! I made a half recipe and this was more than enough for dinner for my husband and I - great heated for leftovers the next day for lunch! My wonton wrappers didn't always stick together when folded but the taste was great. I don't have a steam pot so I fried them to a crisp in the skillet, then added water to steam them. Excellent and they look impressive but I'm not likely to make these often due to the work involved. - Jan '23
the recipe was nice but when i made it didn't go well but thats to blame me so yea. nice recipe though :)

Recipe was very easy to make. I did substitute Bok Choy for the Chinese cabbage and it was delicious. The second to be we used the Chinese cabbage and the taste was so so. Needed a kick off something. Overall we'll keep trying different proteins and continue to bring up the spice level.

Really bland on its own, the sauces don't add much to the dumplings I find. They just taste like pork. I'll be trying what some of the other users suggested in the comments to add a little bit more taste.
I added shrimp.

Good Recipe! I used ground chicken instead of pork. I sautéed the veggies first in olive oil and sesame oil and I added diced mushrooms. I seasoned my chicken with chili flakes, soya sauce, grated ginger and Chinese garlic hot sauce. I took the veggies off the stove and added the chicken. I then moved the mixture to a bowl and added the egg. They turned out amazing!! Soooo flavourful wowzers.
I love this but it takes a long time to prep
I added 1 egg to filling.
The Pork Dumplings were delicious. I had to adapt the recipe because I didn't have Chinese cabbage. I chopped up Bok Choy instead along with a little cilantro and celery. It was wonderful.

I made this with a few items doctored. Great stuff. The best part is I will take the time to make the pork filler and then we just fried up as much as we wanted. I have enough to make it again for my family later this week. 

Also, I recommend if you're frying them, give them an egg-white wash after you've sealed the wonton so they have a nice, golden crispyness.

This recipe was wonderful. I only made a dozen and froze the rest. I scooped 1 T. portions and froze on parchment paper on a cookie sheet. Then when froze, put in a freezer baggie. Will use in soup or make more dumplings.

I realised too late that I only had Pak Choi but I used it anyway and they were delish. Much easier to make than I expected and makes a LOT! Also tip…I would use light soy sauce next time. I used dark this time and it kind of stained them so although they were tasty they weren’t pretty
Very tasty dumplings. Made enough to have a few for leftovers
Excellent !!! I only added 1 tbs of 5 spices
I added Sriracha Chile-garlic sauce because we like all things hot. Sometimes I use the larger wonton wrappers because it the prep goes faster. Great recipe Thank you!

Great recipe, but I'm not eating pork right now so I tried to sub in shredded chicken. Flavor wasn't totally right (that's on me). Next time I wonder if I could try I different TYPE of chicken instead...Korean fried chicken? Something with a bit more flavor/kick?

Honestly so delicious! I should’ve halved the recipe as I ended up with a lot of extras. I froze the extras and boiled them (the ones I had already cooked were steamed in a bamboo steamer) and the dumplings lost their flavor. I’ll have to figure out a better method for next time or just half the recipe.

These are out of this world! I followed the recipe exactly as written. Note that they are time consuming but well worth the effort. You will have a ton of dumplings! Because my pork was previously frozen, I steamed the assembled dumplings, let them cool on a sheet pan then put the pan into the freezer. Once frozen, I stored them in ziplock bags. To cook, defrost and pan fry beef before serving.
Substituted minced cooked mushrooms instead of cabbage since I did not have any
Simple and pretty good. I used turkey instead of pork for I do not like pork very much . Also I cooked everything for a little bit before I wrapped them! Very good and made a lot !!
Doubled spices. Made changes from ACR 4990 and prepared most for freezing using instructions from JennyinHr.
Great recipe! Only thing I did differently was to make my own wrappers and I dipped them in boiling water first before steaming. The filling is excellent.
I’ve made these a couple of times now and as delicious as they are, my filling contracts into a tight dry little ball. Any suggestions on where I might be going wrong as I would love to perfect these

This was awesome! I had to practice for a few minutes to get the amount of filling correct but this worked well for both dumplings and for dim sum. I used bok choy instead of Chinese cabbage and it was delicious.
Very easy and flavorful. I added 6 shrimp to the mixture and pulsed it all in my food processor. Used my Instant Pot to steam them. 3 minutes on manual, 5 minutes natural release then quick release.

BETTER THAN PF CHANGS

This recipe was amazing and delicious!!! The dumplings stuck together because I put too many in a steamer at once, but who has anything against Dumpling Pie???
If you use this recipe for just plain ground pork with rice it works just as well.
We used kale instead same process but very delicious
Added extra garlic and ginger. Tasty!
my family loves it
5 stars for dumplings themselves. I had a problem frying and steaming them. Stuck to my pan, bad. Idk what happened.
Love it. Made double the recipe and froze some so I can just pull them out and steam them when I'm hungry or have friends over

Very flavorful. Followed the recipe. I didn't have quite as much cabbage and a bit more pork but, it still came out great. I froze them before steaming. I fried some also. Yummy! Had some filling left over. Thinking it would be good as a Chinese meatball in soup, over rice with a sauce or even added to meatloaf.
It was a delicious, and I will definitely make it again!

I have made these several times. Takes time to assemble, but so worth it. Used carrots (super easy as I chopped them in a blender) in place of the cabbage. Post steaming, kids love it with a soy sauce and ketchup dip or sauted lightly with in soy and sesame oil. For some spice, I have added a cayenne to the meat mixture and saute post steaming in sriracha, soy, and sesame. With leftover meat filling, I threw in some panko bread crumbs and turned them into meatballs...YUM!
Absolutely amazing. Didnt adjust it at all. Really good dipped in hoisin sauce
Delicious dumplings! I made about 25 for my wife and I to eat and froze the rest in portions. They came out so good I wanted to cry. Thanks!
It turned out perfect!!

Excellent recipe and great as described. I made a few improvements and used 1lb lean ground pork and a half pound of frozen raw shrimp. Also I substituted organic red chard for the cabbage. 

Pan frying gives them a nice crunchy texture. Low-med heat and cover with lid to cook through. Also in my opinion all dumplings should be served with a mixture of rice vinegar and soya sauce.

It tastes delicious! Very much like one you would buy for take out. I steamed these in my bamboo steamer and they held up very well. Only thing is that it is a big production, folding them, cooking them, it’s long!! I definitely recommend this recipe!

These were pretty good! I used the filling for wonton soup and they came out delicious. I used ground chicken because a family member does not eat pork. I added some grated carrot to the mixture. The only change I would make would be to reduce the amount of ginger a little as it seemed a tad too strong for me and I'd like to add a little more garlic next time, but my husband thought they were perfect. My recommendation to others would be to fill 1 wonton, boil, and taste first so you can adjust the seasonings as you want, or cook 1 tsp in a small pan to taste test. Great recipe that is simple and easy to make! Thanks for sharing the recipe!
The dumplings are amazing.
The dumplings are amazing.

This is a family favorite! They're so good! Wrapping them can be a little time consuming but it makes up a lot so well worth it. We always have left overs. I don't make any changes to the recipe. Follow it and you won't be disappointed!
I loved it! Definitely making it again.
The only issue I personally had with the recipe was the portion it made. The product was amazing, amounts though must be tweeked before going into my cookbook.
I followed the recipe as outlined. They were really easy to make and delicious.
delicious but a lot of work
Simple, flavorful and so delicious! We loved them~YUM! Thanks for sharing. :)
These are soo good! I followed the recipe to a tee and oh my gosh I love them. it makes a lot of filling! So I just used what I wanted and then froze the rest of the filling to use at a later date.
My 13 year old son's favorite dish to make. We devour these in minutes every time he makes them.
Will make again. I recommend chili oil, soy sauce, rice wine vinegar, green onion, and sesame seeds for dipping sauce

The pork and chicken sausage turned into a greasy mess. Next time not going to add the sesame oil. Needed more salt. You really need to let the dumplings steam the full time and then some. Don't be tempted to open the lid. I still had to pan fry at the end. Even though I put a tiny amount per dumpling the pork still didn't cook all the au. Next time I'm thinking of frying the meat first and then putting it in the wonton wrapper. My kids love dumplings so I'll muster up the courage to try again.
These are one of the best recipes I have ever made. They take a little while, and I haven't quite mastered folding them up yet, but they are simply fantastic.
Makes a ton of dumplings. Enough for a party. I fried them for a bit to crisp them up. Then dumped a quarter cup of water on top and covered to steam. Worked great, very good!

These dumplings are fantastic! The only change I made was using ground ginger as I had run out of the fresh. I froze them on cookie trays covered with wax paper and then placed them in ziplock bags. They steam very well right out of the freezer.
Very good! I made them for my boyfriend for Chinese New Year and he said they were some of the best he's had... (he's had a lot hahah)

I don't eat pork, so I didn't taste , but made for my family as a main dish. All loved it, asked to have again. Couldn't find won ton wraps, so made in egg roll form. Recipe yielded 12. Didn't take long as others have suggested. Browned pork w ginger root first, then baked. Used kale based cabbage. Nice change from my "regular" meals...will definitely make again, also as appetizers. Thank you!
These are seriously SO good!!!! This recipe is DEF a keeper!

These were AWESOME! Yes, the wrapping is time consuming, but if you get your 16 year old to help you, then it goes much faster. She is a Pot Sticker addict like myself. I also used the rice wine/soy sauce suggestion (adding a touch of chili sauce) to make a dipping sauce. Yes, it makes a large recipe, I cut it in half and still have some in the freezer to use for another time!
Made it with Tofu instead of pork and took out the egg. I basically made it vegan and it turned out to be a success.
These came out so great! I made them up and put them on parchment on a cookie sheet and put them in the freezer for an hour. Then you can just toss them in a freezer bag and cook whenever you want!
Amazing.
Amazing!
They were pretty good, but it took a LONG time to make. They also fell out of the wrapping.

wow these are tasty, I wasn't a total fan of the sauce however it was good I just love tradishtional dumpling dipping sauce. I made one modification and that was doing one tablespoon regular soy sauce and one reduced sodium however I will do it the ordinal way next time just to compare. I was genuinely surprised at how easy these were and dumplings are one of my favorite foods. seriously try this recipie!! Had a problem with folding them so I just did the wonton fold and it was perfect
I didn't add as much cabbage as recipe called for and only could find regular cabbage. Still fantastic! I will definitely make this again. The entire family loved it!
The recipe calls for 100 wantons and will truly make that many!
Really easy and quick to prepare, with lots extra for freezing. I'm no gourmet but you can't mess these up. Would make a great appetizer.

I omit soy sauce and egg, and use a tablespoon of kosher salt split. Cut cabbage and sprinkle two teaspoons of kosher salt on it and toss. Set aside and work on the filling while moisture is drawn out of cabbage. Once filling is complete, wring out cabbage and add to the filling. Two teaspoons of salt seems like a lot, but most will leave with the squeezed out moisture. Add last teaspoon of salt directly to the filling, or use less if you think it is too much salt. I use a piping bag and spray bottle of water to fill and wet the wrappers. I do 9 to 12 wontons at a time. I moisten them all at once with the spray bottle, and then fill and seal. Once sealed, I moisten the outside with the spray bottle, and give each 3 to 6 pleats. I mist finished ones every so often until they make it to the freezer. I cook them directly from frozen. I use a nonstick pan with lid. Place 3/4 to 1 cup of water in the bottom of the pan, and drizzle a tablespoon or two of oil in as well. Put frozen dumplings in the pan and place the lid on tightly. Cook on med-high heat until all the water has boiled off (it will boil off even if lid is tight). Once the water has almost all boiled off, remove the lid and turn down to med-low or low heat until bottom of dumpling are brown and crisp. If you want more sides crisp (mine have 3 sides), flip them. With my assembly line method I can do a whole batch in about an hour, and it makes a BIG bag for freezer.
The flavors were there, but boy did I struggle wrapping and cooking them.

Delicious!! I added shiitake mushrooms and cooked the dumplings by first frying one side for a couple of minutes, then adding 1c water and steaming in the skillet for 5 min. Will definitely make again.

So I had now made these 3 times and made them in batches of 60. I am not stretch a good cook and have fat fingers. These have turned out amazing each time. I do steam them and have learned don't over flour these as the flour gets mealy. When steaming they take 20 minutes and I use sesame oil on the bottom of the double steamer to give them an extra taste.
So good! I didn't change anything. I made a dipping sauce with soy, ginger, and scallions. My husband raved.

I gave a 4 instead of 5 stars only because I found the steaming time to be only 10 minutes rather than the 15-20 suggested in the recipe. They came out very nicely (I added chopped cilantro and minced carrots to the mix to up the nutrient value and flavor). This was my first time making dumplings at home so I followed the recipe closely. I'm pleased with the outcome and thought they tasted just like Chinese takeout. 

For added flavor, I also made a dipping sauce of reduced sodium soy sauce, a teaspoon of toasted sesame oil, red pepper flakes, and a squeeze or two of honey. I let that settle while I made the dumplings. It was a perfect match!

I made it exactly as written with fresh ingredients. Sorry to say we found it to be very dry and bland. It was like mealy pork meatballs wrapped in won tons. Nothing like the wonderful moist dumplings we get from our local restaurant. I will say the use of won ton wrappers was close to what we are used to, the filling is the issue.

These are really tasty! I only had 1 1lb of pork, so I halved all of the other ingredients (except ginger). On another site, they suggested blanching the vegetables, so I did. I used Shanghai Bok Choy, they were really tiny & very tender. I cut off the stems & discarded them, as I only wanted the leaves for this one. I kept the folded dumplings under a damp paper towel as well as the wrappers that were waiting for folding. Apparently, it's important to keep them from drying out. For a first time effort, I was very pleased.

I used pork sausage instead of ground pork and it was amazing!! I did what another reviewer suggested and browned them in a pan with cooking spray, then dumped in a cup of chicken stock and covered, then once all the fluid boiled out I browned again on both sides and they were awesome!
We always improvise a little when we make this. Sometimes we use chicken, sometimes we add carrots, extra ginger, mushrooms etc

Super receipe! Easy to do too. I had always wanted to do this and thought it would be too difficult. I followed the receipe and the use of the egg does seem to bind all together. I did add 1 tablespoon of fried chili paste (super hot) cause we love hot stuff - very hot! They steamed perfectly. Big hit at the house and I will definitly do this again and again.
Made these last night and they were delicious. Easy to assemble and prepare. I scaled down the recipe to feed one but 16 of these actually fed two. Will definitely keep this recipe handy.
Fantastic. The flavour was intense and it was not too difficult to make. I used rice paper sheets because I could not find wonton wrappers at my local supermarket.

I have made these dumplings on several occasions and for different groups of people. They are always a hit and always requested again and again. They are a bit time consuming but soooo worth it!! I also steam them in my bamboo steamer. Just remember to line the steamer with lettuce so the dumplings don't stick to the bamboo. Also, if I have a little more time, I make the mixture the night before, mix well and leave it covered overnight in the frig. FABULOUS!!!!!
I made 2 versions. #1 as written, #2 used beef because DD won't eat pork. Delicious either way! We scarfed these down. Next time, I'll have to double it. Teenagers...bottomless pits!

I wish I could give it higher than a 5 star! I made these using regular cabbage. That's all I had and couldn't find Chinese cabbage. These were amazing! I made them for a party of about 30 people. I made them ahead of time. And thank God I did. The. I made the mixture and let it sit for a few hours to let the cabbage soften. Then stuffed them. I put them on a sheet pan and froze them. When frozen I moved them to a zip lock bag in the freezer. They are very time consuming. But so worth it! The day of the party I would put about 8 in a pot of boiling salted water. Then cook till they floated and a little extra. I couldn't make them fast enough. My husband and brother took over cooking so that I could do other things. But we had two pots going and still not fast enough. I wish I had another way to make them faster or ahead of time. But you don't want them to dry out. They should be moist.
Wonderful flavor. Made it as written but didn't have enough napa cabbage so I substituted regular cabbage to make the 5 cups it called for. Entire family loved it. Will definitely make it again.
Make a billion and freeze them, is awesome

This was the first time I made dumplings, and I would change a few things in my process such as making sure that I don't get as much flour on them before I steam them. But I do have to say that I love steaming them - it's so much healthier than frying them. All in all, not bad. I enjoyed these.
I just love Asian cuisine

These are the best I have made. The only thing I recommend is that you lightly use olive oil on the outside of the dumplings before placing them on a metal steamer. Mine stuck to the steamer and it was a big fat mess to get them off of it. Still worth the hassle though!
I followed the recipe as indicated. I also made the Dumpling Dipping Sauce from this site.
These were amazing! I froze half the recipe and had them for a late night snack! From the freezer to the steamer! Sooooooo good!

These taste wonderful and they're great for our budget because the recipe yields so many. My husband has determined that we must have them at least once a month. I agree. The leftovers make my lunch break at work magical.
real winner

This is a great recipe. I froze them and a few days later added them to homemade chicken broth, lemon grass, egg, and before serving a splash of sesame oil and chopped scallions as a tasty soup. Delicious!
This recipe is a must try. Easy to make.

Going to use this recipe forever. TIP if you do not have a steamer I Youtubed it and just prepare a large pot of boiling water a metal rack to place on top of the pot and a large skillet to cover your dumplings
only one word OUTSTANDING!! Just make them
Followed the recipe exactly, These were incredible my whole family loved them. I made my own dough for the wrappers and steamed them, served with sweet chili sauce and a soya sauce dip, yum!
